CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 8;Not necessary to examine Art. 13;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings;Costs and expenses award - domestic proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . PERSON , a NORP national born in DATE , lives at FAC .

CARDINAL . In the course of a judicial investigation into offences of theft , burglary , handling the proceeds of theft and aggravated theft , and unlawful possession of Class CARDINAL weapons and ammunition , an investigating judge at PERSON issued a warrant on DATE instructing the gendarmerie to arrange for the telephone line of a certain PERSON to be tapped until DATE .

CARDINAL . By means of standard - form written instructions ( “ soit transmis ” ) dated DATE , DATE and DATE , the investigating judge extended the duration of the telephone tapping until DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE respectively .

CARDINAL . As a result of this tapping and the interception of some of his conversations , the applicant was charged with handling the proceeds of aggravated theft ; he was held in custody from DATE to CARDINAL DATE , when he was released subject to judicial supervision .

CARDINAL . In an application of DATE the applicant ’s lawyer applied to ORG of ORG for a ruling that the extensions of DATE and CARDINAL DATE were invalid , arguing that they had been ordered merely by standard - form written instructions without any reference to the offences which justified the telephone tapping , and that the DATE period which could have been authorised in the warrant of CARDINAL DATE had expired on DATE .
CARDINAL . NORP In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed PERSON application on the following grounds :

“ … by Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW [ see paragraph CARDINAL below ] taken together , decisions to intercept telecommunications messages must be in writing and contain all the information necessary for identifying the link to be monitored , the offence that justifies the interception and the duration of the interception , which must not exceed DATE but may be extended subject to the same formal requirements and maximum duration .

In the instant case it is beyond doubt that the warrant of CARDINAL DATE complies with the requirements of the above - mentioned ORG in so far as it specifies the number of the link to be monitored , a duration of DATE and the offences that justified interception , the criminal penalties for which were greater than DATE imprisonment .

It is also clear that the decisions to extend the duration of the interception , which were issued in standard - form instructions , were in writing and mentioned the number of the link concerned ; that they are an extension of the original decision of DATE and necessarily referred to it ; and that the duration of their validity was DATE . They thus comply with the requirements of LAW . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on a point of law against the judgment of CARDINAL DATE , arguing , as his only ground of appeal , that LAW seq . of LAW had been infringed because the extensions of the duration of the telephone tapping in issue , by means of standard - form written instructions , did not contain any reasons .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG affirmed the decision appealed against and held that the applicant had “ no locus standi to challenge the manner in which the duration of the monitoring of a third party ’s telephone line was extended ” and that accordingly “ the grounds of appeal , which contest[ed ] the grounds on which ORG [ had ] wrongly considered it must examine [ the ] objections of invalidity and subsequently dismissed them , [ were ] inadmissible ” .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of LAW no . CARDINAL of DATE on the confidentiality of telecommunications messages ) read as follows :
Article CARDINAL

“ In the case of a serious crime or other major offence attracting a sentence of DATE imprisonment , the investigating judge may , where necessary for the investigation , order the interception , recording and transcription of telecommunications messages . Such operations shall be carried out under his authority and supervision .
Decisions to intercept shall be in writing . They shall not constitute judicial decisions and no appeal shall lie against them . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ Decisions made pursuant to LAW shall contain all the information necessary for identifying the link to be monitored , the offence that justifies the interception and the duration of the interception . ”
Article CARDINAL
“ Such decisions shall be valid for a maximum duration of DATE . Their validity may be extended only subject to the same procedural requirements and maximum duration . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ The investigating judge or a senior detective ( officier de police judiciaire ) acting on his instructions may call upon any qualified official of any department or body under the authority or supervision of the Minister for Telecommunications , or any qualified official of an authorised network operator or provider of telecommunications services , for the purpose of installing monitoring equipment . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ The investigating judge or the senior detective acting on his instructions shall draw up a report on each of the interception and recording operations . This report shall give the date and time of the beginning and end of each operation . ”
Article CARDINAL

“ The investigating judge or the senior detective acting on his instructions shall transcribe messages useful for establishing the truth . A report of the transcription shall be drawn up and the transcription placed in the case file .
Any messages in a foreign language shall be transcribed in NORP with the help of an interpreter called upon for this purpose . ”
Article CARDINAL
“ ORG or ORG shall ensure that the recordings are destroyed when prosecution becomes time - barred .
A formal report of the destruction shall be drawn up . ”
Article CARDINAL - CARDINAL
“ The telephone line of a member of ORG or senator shall not be tapped unless and until the Speaker of the relevant ORG has been informed by the investigating judge .
The home or office telephone lines of a member of the Bar shall not be tapped unless and until the chairman of the Bar has been informed by the investigating judge .
Any interception carried out in breach of the requirements of this Article shall be null and void . ”

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON applied to the Commission on DATE . He alleged that the interception of certain telephone conversations which were used against him amounted to interference with his private life and correspondence , contrary to LAW ; he also maintained that he had not had an effective remedy in ORG , contrary to LAW .

CARDINAL . The Commission declared the application ( no . CARDINAL ) admissible on DATE . In its report of DATE ( Article CARDINAL ) , it expressed the opinion by QUANTITY votes to QUANTITY that there had been a violation of LAW and by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL that it was unnecessary to consider the case under LAW also . The full text of the ORG ’s opinion and of the CARDINAL dissenting opinions contained in the report is reproduced as an annex to this judgment .
CARDINAL . In their memorial the Government submitted that “ the application lodged by PERSON should be dismissed ” .
CARDINAL . The applicant asked the ORG to
“ hold that there has been a violation of LAW ;
award him MONEY by way of just satisfaction ” .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON submitted that ORG decision to refuse him any standing to complain of the interception of some of his telephone conversations , on the ground that it was a third party ’s line that had been tapped , had infringed LAW , which provides :
“ CARDINAL . Everyone has the right to respect for his private and family life , his home and his correspondence .

CARDINAL . There shall be no interference by a public authority with the exercise of this right except such as is in accordance with the law and is necessary in a NORP society in the interests of national security , public safety or the economic well - being of the country , for the prevention of disorder or crime , for the protection of health or morals , or for the protection of the rights and freedoms of others . ”

CARDINAL . The ORG points out that as telephone conversations are covered by the notions of “ private life ” and “ correspondence ” within the meaning of Article CARDINAL , the admitted measure of interception amounted to “ interference by a public authority ” with the exercise of a right secured to the applicant in paragraph CARDINAL of that Article ( see , among other authorities , the following judgments : PERSON v. the GPE , DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ; ORG v. GPE and PERSON v. GPE , DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL-A and B , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , and p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ; PERSON v. the GPE , DATE , Reports of Judgments and Decisions CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL–CARDINAL , § DATE ; and PERSON v. GPE , DATE , Reports CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § MONEY ) . In this connection , it is of little importance
that the telephone tapping in question was carried out on the line of a third party .
The Government did not dispute this .

CARDINAL . Such interference will contravene LAW unless it is “ in accordance with the law ” , pursues CARDINAL or more of the legitimate aims referred to in paragraph CARDINAL and furthermore is “ necessary in a NORP society ” in order to achieve them .

CARDINAL . The expression “ in accordance with the law ” within the meaning of LAW requires , firstly , that the impugned measure should have some basis in domestic law ; it also refers to the quality of the law in question , requiring that it should be accessible to the person concerned , who must moreover be able to foresee its consequences for him , and compatible with the rule of law .

CARDINAL . The ORG notes that the investigating judge ordered the telephone tapping in question on the basis of Articles CARDINAL et seq . of the Code of Criminal Procedure ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) .
CARDINAL . The interference complained of therefore had a statutory basis in NORP law .
CARDINAL . The second requirement which derives from the phrase “ in accordance with the law ” – the accessibility of DATE does not raise any problem in the instant case .

CARDINAL . As to the “ foreseeability of the law ” , the ORG maintained that following the ORG ’s judgments in the ORG and PERSON cases ( see paragraph QUANTITY above ) , the NORP legislature had remedied the omissions and weaknesses of domestic law on telephone tapping by adopting safeguards in respect of the persons whose telephones could be tapped , the duration of interception , the requirements for drawing up reports , and the communication or destruction of recordings .

CARDINAL . The ORG considers , as the ORG did , that Articles CARDINAL et seq . of the Code of Criminal Procedure , inserted by the PERSON of DATE on the confidentiality of telecommunications messages , lay down clear , detailed rules and specify with sufficient clarity the scope and manner of exercise of the relevant discretion conferred on the public authorities ( see the PERSON and PERSON judgments cited above , pp . CARDINAL–CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL–CARDINAL , and p. CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL–CARDINAL , respectively , and , as the most recent authority and mutatis mutandis , the PERSON judgment cited above , pp . CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL–CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG shares the opinion of the Government and the Commission and considers that the interference was designed to establish the truth in connection with criminal proceedings and therefore to prevent disorder .

CARDINAL . It remains to be ascertained whether the interference was “ necessary in a NORP society ” for achieving those objectives . Under the ORG ’s settled case - law , GPE enjoy a certain margin of appreciation in assessing the existence and extent of such necessity , but this margin is subject to NORP supervision , embracing both the legislation and the decisions applying it , even those given by an independent court ( see , mutatis mutandis , the Silver and Others v. the GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL–CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , and the PERSON v. GPE judgment of CARDINAL DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . When considering the necessity of interference , the ORG stated in its PERSON and Others v. GPE judgment of DATE ( Series A no . CARDINAL , pp . CARDINAL and CARDINAL–CARDINAL , § § DATE ) :

“ The ORG must be satisfied that , whatever system of surveillance is adopted , there exist adequate and effective guarantees against abuse . This assessment has only a relative character : it depends on … [ among other things ] the kind of remedy provided by the national law .

It therefore has to be determined whether the procedures for supervising the ordering and implementation of the restrictive measures are such as to keep the ‘ interference’ resulting from the contested legislation to what is ‘ necessary in a democratic society’ .

… In addition , the values of a NORP society must be followed as faithfully as possible in the supervisory procedures if the bounds of necessity , within the meaning of LAW , are not to be exceeded . CARDINAL of the fundamental principles of a democratic society is the rule of law , which is expressly referred to in the LAW to the Convention … The rule of law implies , inter alia , that an interference by the executive authorities with an individual ’s rights should be subject to an effective control … ”

CARDINAL . The applicant said that he had wished to complain of the circumstances in which the investigating judge had ordered the extensions of the duration of the telephone tapping ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , but ORG decision had deprived him of any practical possibility of using the remedies provided by law to penalise irregularities committed by the authorities .

CARDINAL . In the ORG ’s submission , the interference complained of had been “ necessary in a NORP society ” . In the instant case the telephone tapping had been one of the principal means of investigation contributing to the establishment of the truth and , in particular , to proving the involvement of various individuals , including the applicant , in large - scale illicit dealing in furniture . Furthermore , PERSON had been able to avail himself of a remedy in ORG , and a further remedy in ORG was quite unnecessary to satisfy the requirement of “ effective control ” .
CARDINAL . The ORG must accordingly ascertain whether an “ effective control ” was available to PERSON to challenge the telephone tapping to which he had been made subject .

CARDINAL . It notes , firstly , that ORG in its judgment of DATE held that the applicant had “ no locus standi to challenge the manner in which the duration of the monitoring of a third party ’s telephone line was extended ” and that accordingly “ the grounds of appeal , which contest[ed ] the grounds on which ORG [ had ] wrongly considered it must examine [ the ] objections of invalidity and subsequently dismissed them , [ were ] inadmissible ” .

CARDINAL . In its ruling ORG therefore went beyond the ground relied on by the applicant concerning the extension of the duration of the telephone tapping and held that a victim of the tapping of a telephone line not his own has no standing to invoke the protection of national law or LAW . It concluded that in the instant case ORG had been wrong to examine the objections of invalidity raised by the applicant as the telephone line being monitored had not been his own .

CARDINAL . Admittedly , the applicant had been able to avail himself of a remedy in respect of the disputed point in ORG , which held that the investigating judge ’s extension of the duration of the telephone tapping had been in accordance with Articles CARDINAL et seq . of the Code of Criminal Procedure ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , and it is not the ORG ’s function to express an opinion on the interpretation of domestic law , which is primarily for the national courts to interpret ( see the PERSON and PERSON judgments cited above , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , and p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , respectively ) . However , ORG , the guardian of national law , criticised ORG for having examined the merits of PERSON application .

CARDINAL . As the ORG has already said ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the provisions of the PERSON of DATE governing telephone tapping satisfy the requirements of LAW and those laid down in the PERSON and PERSON judgments . However , it has to be recognised that ORG reasoning could lead to decisions whereby a very large number of people are deprived of the protection of the law , namely all those who have conversations on a telephone line other than their own . That would in practice render the protective machinery largely devoid of substance .

CARDINAL . That was the case with the applicant , who did not enjoy the effective protection of national law , which does not make any distinction according to whose line is being tapped ( Articles CARDINAL et seq . of LAW see paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . The ORG therefore considers , like the Commission , that the applicant did not have available to him the “ effective control ” to which citizens are entitled under the rule of law and which would have been capable of restricting the interference in question to what was “ necessary in a NORP society ” .
CARDINAL . There has consequently been a violation of LAW .
CARDINAL . The applicant also alleged a violation of LAW , which provides :

“ Everyone whose rights and freedoms as set forth in [ the ] Convention are violated shall have an effective remedy before a national authority notwithstanding that the violation has been committed by persons acting in an official capacity . ”
CARDINAL . In view of the preceding conclusion ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , the ORG does not consider that it need rule on the complaint in question .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the ORG provides :

“ If the ORG finds that a decision or a measure taken by a legal authority or any other authority of a High Contracting Party is completely or partially in conflict with the obligations arising from the ... Convention , and if the internal law of the said ORG allows only partial reparation to be made for the consequences of this decision or measure , the decision of the ORG shall , if necessary , afford just satisfaction to the injured party . ”
CARDINAL . Mr PERSON sought MONEY ( FRF ) for non - pecuniary damage .
CARDINAL . The Government considered that any finding of a violation would constitute sufficient just satisfaction .
CARDINAL . The Delegate of the Commission expressed no view on the matter .
CARDINAL . The ORG considers that the applicant undeniably sustained non - pecuniary damage and awards him the sum of FRF CARDINAL under this head .
CARDINAL . The applicant also claimed ORG CARDINAL in respect of the costs and expenses incurred in the proceedings before the ORG .
CARDINAL . The Government considered that the amount claimed was not unreasonable and wished to leave the matter to the ORG ’s discretion .
CARDINAL . The Delegate of the Commission did not express a view .
CARDINAL . Making its assessment on an equitable basis and with reference to its usual criteria , the ORG awards the sum claimed .
CARDINAL . According to the information available to the ORG , the statutory rate of interest applicable in GPE at the date of adoption of the present judgment is PERCENT per annum .
